title: What does it mean to be a refugee? - Benedetta Berti and Evelien Borgman

multiple-choice.question: What is the estimated number of people worldwide who have been forced to leave their homes due to war, violence, and persecution?

options.label: A
options.text: 10 million

options.label: B
options.text: 30 million

options.label: C
options.text: 60 million

options.label: D
options.text: 100 million

multiple-choice.question: According to the UN's 1951 Convention, what is the definition of a refugee?

options.label: A
options.text: Someone who is outside their country of nationality and is unable to return due to economic reasons.

options.label: B
options.text: Someone who is outside their country of nationality and is unable to return due to well-founded fears of being persecuted.

options.label: C
options.text: Someone who is inside their country of nationality and is unable to leave due to war and violence.

options.label: D
options.text: Someone who is inside their country of nationality and is unable to leave due to economic reasons.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between a migrant and a refugee?

options.label: A
options.text: A migrant is someone who leaves their country for economic reasons, while a refugee is someone who leaves due to persecution.

options.label: B
options.text: A migrant is someone who leaves their country for persecution, while a refugee is someone who leaves due to economic reasons.

options.label: C
options.text: A migrant is someone who leaves their country temporarily, while a refugee is someone who leaves permanently.

options.label: D
options.text: A migrant is someone who leaves their country with a visa, while a refugee is someone who leaves without a visa.

multiple-choice.question: What is the principle of non-refoulement in the context of refugees?

options.label: A
options.text: The principle that a nation must send an individual back to their home country if they are not granted refugee status.

options.label: B
options.text: The principle that a nation must not send an individual to a country where their life and freedom are threatened.

options.label: C
options.text: The principle that a nation must provide a minimum standard of treatment to refugees.

options.label: D
options.text: The principle that a nation must allow refugees to enter the workforce.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is a major challenge faced by refugee children?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of access to healthcare

options.label: B
options.text: Lack of access to education

options.label: C
options.text: Lack of access to food and water

options.label: D
options.text: Lack of access to shelter

title: Are You A Good Listener?

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the most important life skills that few people know how to do?

options.label: A
options.text: Being a good speaker

options.label: B
options.text: Being a good listener

options.label: C
options.text: Being a good writer

options.label: D
options.text: Being a good leader

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one thing that a good listener does to make conversation more enjoyable?

options.label: A
options.text: They interrupt frequently to share their own thoughts

options.label: B
options.text: They egg us on and encourage us to elaborate

options.label: C
options.text: They moralize and offer unsolicited advice

options.label: D
options.text: They change the subject frequently

multiple-choice.question: What is the goal of a good listener when they urge clarification?

options.label: A
options.text: To simply agree or disagree with what we say

options.label: B
options.text: To explore the deeper attitudes and underlying issues behind what we say

options.label: C
options.text: To change the subject and move on to something else

options.label: D
options.text: To offer their own opinion and advice

multiple-choice.question: How do good listeners respond to our vulnerabilities and follies?

options.label: A
options.text: They criticize and judge us harshly

options.label: B
options.text: They offer unsolicited advice and try to fix the problem

options.label: C
options.text: They make occasional little positive sounds and signal sympathy without intruding

options.label: D
options.text: They ignore and dismiss our concerns

multiple-choice.question: What is one way that good listeners separate disagreement from criticism?

options.label: A
options.text: They avoid disagreeing with us altogether

options.label: B
options.text: They make it clear that they can like us and still think we're wrong

options.label: C
options.text: They become defensive and argumentative when we disagree

options.label: D
options.text: They try to change the subject and avoid conflict

options.label: B

title: Why is the US Constitution so hard to amend? - Peter Paccone

options.label: B
options.text: A two-thirds vote of approval in both houses of Congress, or a request from two-thirds of state legislatures to call a national convention

options.text: A majority vote in both houses of Congress

options.label: B

title: The Turing test: Can a computer pass for a human? - Alex Gendler

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Catherine

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: It mimicked a psychologist and reflected people's questions back at them.

options.label: C
options.text: It used complex algorithms to generate human-like responses.

options.label: D
options.text: It was able to learn from experience and adapt to new situations.

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the challenges that chatbots face in simulating human conversations?

options.label: A
options.text: They lack the ability to process large amounts of data.

options.label: B
options.text: They are unable to recognize and respond to human emotions.

options.label: C
options.text: They struggle to deal with simple pauses and questions with no correct answer.

options.label: D
options.text: They are unable to learn from experience and adapt to new situations.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one of the key factors that has allowed some chatbots to succeed in passing the Turing test?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to process large amounts of data.

options.label: B
options.text: Their ability to recognize and respond to human emotions.

options.label: C
options.text: Their use of clever strategies to fool judges, such as mimicking a particular persona or topic.

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to learn from experience and adapt to new situations.

title: Does grammar matter? - Andreea S. Calude

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary difference between prescriptivism and descriptivism in linguistics?

options.label: A
options.text: Prescriptivism focuses on spoken language, while descriptivism focuses on written language.

options.label: B
options.text: Prescriptivism emphasizes the importance of following consistent rules, while descriptivism sees variation and adaptation as natural and necessary.

options.label: C
options.text: Prescriptivism is concerned with the history of language, while descriptivism is concerned with the present state of language.

options.label: D
options.text: Prescriptivism is used in formal contexts, while descriptivism is used in informal contexts.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why written language was standardized in many languages?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a single, unified language for all people to speak.

options.label: B
options.text: To allow broader communication and ensure that people in different parts of a realm could understand each other.

options.label: C
options.text: To establish a set of rules for spoken language.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a language that was separate from spoken language.

multiple-choice.question: According to descriptivists, how do people form their spoken repertoire?

options.label: A
options.text: Through memorized rules and conscious effort.

options.label: B
options.text: Through unconscious habits and exposure to language at an early age.

options.label: C
options.text: Through reading and writing.

options.label: D
options.text: Through imitation of others.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of descriptivism in linguistics?

options.label: A
options.text: To dictate how language should be used.

options.label: B
options.text: To describe how people actually use language and track innovations.

options.label: C
options.text: To establish a set of rules for written language.

options.label: D
options.text: To create a standardized form of language.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between prescriptivism and descriptivism?

options.label: A
options.text: They are mutually exclusive and cannot coexist.

options.label: B
options.text: They are complementary and can inform each other.

options.label: C
options.text: Prescriptivism is a subset of descriptivism.

options.label: D
options.text: Descriptivism is a subset of prescriptivism.

What is one of the key factors contributing to the success of insects?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to fly

options.label: B
options.text: Their impressive ability to breed

options.label: C
options.text: Their large size

options.label: D
options.text: Their slow rate of reproduction

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an insect that can survive in an extreme environment?

options.label: A
options.text: A butterfly that can survive in temperatures above 100 degrees Fahrenheit

options.label: B
options.text: A beetle that can live at -40 degrees Fahrenheit

options.label: C
options.text: A mosquito that can survive in high altitudes

options.label: D
options.text: An ant that can survive underwater

multiple-choice.question: What is the term for the process by which some insects undergo a complete transformation from a larval stage to an adult stage?

options.label: A
options.text: Metamorphosis

options.label: B
options.text: Hibernation

options.label: C
options.text: Migration

options.label: D
options.text: Camouflage

title: How ancient art influenced modern art - Felipe Galindo

multiple-choice.question: What is the term "modern art" referring to in the context of art history?

options.label: A
options.text: Art that is currently popular

options.label: B
options.text: A style of art that originated over 150 years ago

options.label: C
options.text: Art that is created using modern technology

options.label: D
options.text: Art that is only found in modern museums

multiple-choice.question: Which artist's visit to the Trocadéro Ethnographic Museum in Paris in 1907 had a significant impact on the development of modern art?

options.label: A
options.text: Henri Matisse

options.label: B
options.text: Pablo Picasso

options.label: C
options.text: Paul Gauguin

options.label: D
options.text: Vincent Van Gogh

multiple-choice.question: What was the inspiration behind Picasso's painting "Les Demoiselles d'Avignon"?

options.label: A
options.text: Ancient Iberian art

options.label: B
options.text: African masks

options.label: C
options.text: Polynesian lore

options.label: D
options.text: A combination of European themes and African masks

multiple-choice.question: Which artist based many of his semi-abstract bronze sculptures on a replica of a chacmool from the Toltec-Maya culture?

options.label: A
options.text: Constantin Brâncuși

options.label: B
options.text: Amedeo Modigliani

options.label: C
options.text: Henry Moore

options.label: D
options.text: Josef Albers

multiple-choice.question: What is a criticism that can be made of the modern artists who drew inspiration from ancient cultures?

options.label: A
options.text: They were not skilled enough to create original work

options.label: B
options.text: They were appropriating ideas and profiting from cultures they considered primitive

options.label: C
options.text: They were not knowledgeable enough about the cultures they were drawing from

options.label: D
options.text: They were not creating art that was relevant to their own time period

title: Why do we love? A philosophical inquiry - Skye C. Cleary

multiple-choice.question: According to Plato, why do humans love?

options.label: A
options.text: To find a soulmate who will make us feel whole again.

options.label: B
options.text: To procreate and maintain the species.

options.label: C
options.text: To escape our loneliness and fear of the world.

options.label: D
options.text: To satisfy our base desires.

multiple-choice.question: What did Arthur Schopenhauer believe about love?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a way to find true happiness and fulfillment.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a trick of nature to get us to procreate.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a way to escape our loneliness and fear of the world.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a great source of suffering.

multiple-choice.question: According to Bertrand Russell, what is the purpose of love?

options.label: A
options.text: To satisfy our physical and psychological desires.

options.label: B
options.text: To find a soulmate who will make us feel whole again.

options.label: C
options.text: To escape our loneliness and fear of the world.

options.label: D
options.text: To procreate and maintain the species.

multiple-choice.question: What did Siddhārtha Gautama (the Buddha) believe about love?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a way to find true happiness and fulfillment.

options.label: B
options.text: It is a trick of nature to get us to procreate.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a great source of suffering.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a way to escape our loneliness and fear of the world.

multiple-choice.question: According to Simone de Beauvoir, what is the key to loving authentically?

options.label: A
options.text: Dependence on another to justify our existence.

options.label: B
options.text: Loving someone as a means to an end.

options.label: C
options.text: Supporting each other in discovering ourselves and reaching beyond ourselves.

options.label: D
options.text: Making love our only reason for being.

title: What outer space does to your body

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the spine in a zero-gravity environment?

options.label: A
options.text: It compresses and becomes shorter.

options.label: B
options.text: It elongates and becomes taller.

options.label: C
options.text: It remains the same.

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes curved.

multiple-choice.question: Why does the heart change shape and size in space?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it has to pump harder to pull blood up from the feet.

options.label: B
options.text: Because it has to pump easier since the blood is floating.

options.label: C
options.text: Because it is affected by the lack of oxygen in space.

options.label: D
options.text: Because it is affected by the change in temperature in space.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the bones in a zero-gravity environment?

options.label: A
options.text: They become stronger and denser.

options.label: B
options.text: They remain the same.

options.label: C
options.text: They lose calcium and become more brittle.

options.label: D
options.text: They become more flexible.

multiple-choice.question: Why do astronauts wear glasses in space?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the lack of gravity affects their vision.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the change in air pressure affects their vision.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the intracranial pressure changes and pushes on the eyeball.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they forget their contact lenses on Earth.

multiple-choice.question: Why do astronauts run on a treadmill in space?

options.label: A
options.text: To stay physically fit and healthy.

options.label: B
options.text: To give loads to their bones and prevent atrophy.

options.label: C
options.text: To test the effects of zero gravity on their bodies.

options.label: D
options.text: To prepare for landing back on Earth.

title: History vs. Napoleon Bonaparte - Alex Gendler

multiple-choice.question: What was the average height of Napoléon Bonaparte compared to his contemporaries?

options.label: A
options.text: He was significantly shorter than average.

options.label: B
options.text: He was at least average height for his time.

options.label: C
options.text: He was significantly taller than average.

options.label: D
options.text: His height is unknown.

multiple-choice.question: What was the state of the French government before Napoléon seized power?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a stable and competent democracy.

options.label: B
options.text: It was an unstable and incompetent oligarchy.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a powerful and centralized monarchy.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a decentralized and feudal system.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of Napoléon's new constitution and legal code on the French Revolution's achievements?

options.label: A
options.text: It completely abolished all the revolution's achievements.

options.label: B
options.text: It kept some of the most important achievements intact.

options.label: C
options.text: It introduced a new set of contradictory laws.

options.label: D
options.text: It had no impact on the revolution's achievements.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Napoléon's military campaigns across Europe?

options.label: A
options.text: Millions dead and the international order shattered.

options.label: B
options.text: A lasting peace and stability across the continent.

options.label: C
options.text: The spread of democratic and liberal ideals only in France.

options.label: D
options.text: The rise of nationalism and increased army sizes only in Britain.

multiple-choice.question: What was the long-term impact of Napoléon's conquests on European history?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a return to feudalism and absolute monarchies.

options.label: B
options.text: It resulted in the spread of democratic and liberal ideals across Europe.

options.label: C
options.text: It had no lasting impact on European history.

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the rise of communism and socialism.

title: #TEDEdChat: Redefining Leadership | Drew Dudley | Leading with Lollipops |

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why do people often hesitate to call themselves leaders?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they think leadership is only for special occasions.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they believe leadership is about changing the world.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they think leadership is only for people in positions of power.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are afraid of being seen as arrogant.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "lollipop moment" that the speaker refers to?

options.label: A
options.text: A moment when someone does something embarrassing.

options.label: B
options.text: A moment when someone makes a significant impact on someone's life.

options.label: C
options.text: A moment when someone achieves a great success.

options.label: D
options.text: A moment when someone fails at something.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the problem with the way we typically think about leadership?

options.label: A
options.text: We think it's too easy to be a leader.

options.label: B
options.text: We think it's only for certain people.

options.label: C
options.text: We make it about changing the world, rather than making a difference in individual lives.

options.label: D
options.text: We don't think it's important.

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker mean by "redefining leadership"?

options.label: A
options.text: Making leadership more exclusive.

options.label: B
options.text: Making leadership about achieving great successes.

options.label: C
options.text: Making leadership about making a positive impact on individual lives.

options.label: D
options.text: Making leadership about holding a position of power.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the quote from Marianne Williamson about?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of being humble.

options.label: B
options.text: The power of leadership.

options.label: C
options.text: The fear of being inadequate.

options.label: D
options.text: The fear of being powerful beyond measure.

title: The beneficial bacteria that make delicious food - Erez Garty

multiple-choice.question: What is responsible for the fluffiness of bread?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of yeast in the dough

options.label: B
options.text: The high sugar content in the dough

options.label: C
options.text: The type of flour used in the dough

options.label: D
options.text: The temperature at which the bread is baked

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of yeast in the production of wine?

options.label: A
options.text: To consume oxygen and produce carbon dioxide

options.label: B
options.text: To consume sugar and produce ethanol

options.label: C
options.text: To consume ethanol and produce acetic acid

options.label: D
options.text: To consume carbon dioxide and produce oxygen

multiple-choice.question: What type of bacteria is responsible for converting ethanol in wine into acetic acid?

options.label: A
options.text: Lactic acid bacteria

options.label: B
options.text: Acetic acid bacteria

options.label: C
options.text: Carbon dioxide bacteria

options.label: D
options.text: Ethanol bacteria

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of adding rennet to milk in the cheese-making process?

options.label: A
options.text: To introduce bacteria into the milk

options.label: B
options.text: To speed up the fermentation process

options.label: C
options.text: To help the proteins in the milk aggregate and curdle

options.label: D
options.text: To add flavor to the cheese

multiple-choice.question: What type of microorganism is responsible for the characteristic holes in Swiss cheese?

options.label: A
options.text: Yeast

options.label: B
options.text: Bacteria that emit carbon dioxide

options.label: C
options.text: Mold

options.label: D
options.text: Lactic acid bacteria
